message_1:
Which of the following propositional logic statements are logically equivalent: 

(A) p ∧ q 
(B) ¬(¬p ∨ ¬q) 

How many logically equivalent propositions are there?
message_2:
To determine if the two propositional logic statements are logically equivalent, we can use the properties of logical equivalence and De Morgan's laws.

(A) p ∧ q

(B) ¬(¬p ∨ ¬q)

According to De Morgan's laws, the negation of a disjunction is equivalent to the conjunction of the negations:

¬(A ∨ B) ≡ ¬A ∧ ¬B

Applying De Morgan's laws to (B):

¬(¬p ∨ ¬q) ≡ ¬¬p ∧ ¬¬q

Since the double negation cancels out:

¬¬p ≡ p
¬¬q ≡ q

So, (B) becomes:

p ∧ q

Now, comparing (A) and (B):

(A) p ∧ q
(B) p ∧ q

Both statements are the same, so they are logically equivalent.

There are 2 logically equivalent propositions in this case: (A) and (B).
